content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Certain pathogens have what is known as a mutator phenotype associated with a high frequency of <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutations that enable them to change rapidly. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that causes severe infections that are often difficult to treat. Scientists assessed whether strains of C. neoformans possess a mutator phenotype. The scientists analyzed eleven wild, environmental strains (<math alttext="E 1 "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="E 11"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and eleven clinical isolate strains (from patients, <math alttext="C 1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="C 11"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) of C. neoformans. The scientists inoculated an equal number of cells from each strain into 20 replicate liquid cultures in test tubes. After a period of growth, they removed cells from each culture and plated the cells on petri dishes containing a solid growth medium with a chemical that is typically toxic to the fungi. After an incubation period, the scientists counted the number of colonies (each colony is derived from division of a single cell) that grew in each dish and combined the data from the 20 dishes for each strain. Representative data are shown in Figure 1. The data for all environmental strains resembled the data shown for strains <math alttext="E 1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E 4"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E 10"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data for all clinical strains except strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> resembled the data shown for strain <math alttext="C 8"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C8</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 1. Number of colonies produced from C. neoformans cells grown on a medium containing a toxic chemical. Representative data from 11 environmental (<math alttext="E"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) strains and 11 clinical isolate strains (<math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In a further experiment, the scientists investigated the mechanism responsible for the greater number of colonies produced by strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than by the other strains. Based on <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sequence analyses of the strains, the scientists introduced a wild-type copy of the fungal <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene, a gene encoding a repair enzyme involved in identifying nucleotides in <math alttext="D N A "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that contain incorrect bases, into cells of strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and again analyzed the number of colonies that grew in the presence of the toxic chemical (Figure 2). Figure 2. Number of colonies produced from C. neoformans strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells grown on a medium containing a toxic chemical. A wild-type copy of the fungal <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene was introduced into strains <math alttext="C 3 hyphen M S H 2 superscript plus"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3-</mtext><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and <math alttext="C 6 hyphen M S H 2 superscript plus"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6-</mtext><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>. The plasmid into which the <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene was cloned for introduction into the fungi is present in strains <math alttext="C 3 hyphen P B B"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6 hyphen P B B"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe why <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication is said to be a semiconservative process. Explain how random mutations such as those in pathogens with a mutator phenotype may arise in the <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of an organism.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Certain pathogens have what is known as a mutator phenotype associated with a high frequency of <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutations that enable them to change rapidly. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that causes severe infections that are often difficult to treat. Scientists assessed whether strains of C. neoformans possess a mutator phenotype. The scientists analyzed eleven wild, environmental strains (<math alttext="E 1 "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="E 11"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and eleven clinical isolate strains (from patients, <math alttext="C 1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> through <math alttext="C 11"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) of C. neoformans. The scientists inoculated an equal number of cells from each strain into 20 replicate liquid cultures in test tubes. After a period of growth, they removed cells from each culture and plated the cells on petri dishes containing a solid growth medium with a chemical that is typically toxic to the fungi. After an incubation period, the scientists counted the number of colonies (each colony is derived from division of a single cell) that grew in each dish and combined the data from the 20 dishes for each strain. Representative data are shown in Figure 1. The data for all environmental strains resembled the data shown for strains <math alttext="E 1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E 4"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E 10"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data for all clinical strains except strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> resembled the data shown for strain <math alttext="C 8"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C8</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 1. Number of colonies produced from C. neoformans cells grown on a medium containing a toxic chemical. Representative data from 11 environmental (<math alttext="E"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) strains and 11 clinical isolate strains (<math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In a further experiment, the scientists investigated the mechanism responsible for the greater number of colonies produced by strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than by the other strains. Based on <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sequence analyses of the strains, the scientists introduced a wild-type copy of the fungal <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene, a gene encoding a repair enzyme involved in identifying nucleotides in <math alttext="D N A "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that contain incorrect bases, into cells of strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and again analyzed the number of colonies that grew in the presence of the toxic chemical (Figure 2). Figure 2. Number of colonies produced from C. neoformans strains <math alttext="C 3"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells grown on a medium containing a toxic chemical. A wild-type copy of the fungal <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene was introduced into strains <math alttext="C 3 hyphen M S H 2 superscript plus"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3-</mtext><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and <math alttext="C 6 hyphen M S H 2 superscript plus"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6-</mtext><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>. The plasmid into which the <math alttext="M S H 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>H</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> gene was cloned for introduction into the fungi is present in strains <math alttext="C 3 hyphen P B B"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6 hyphen P B B"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe why <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication is said to be a semiconservative process. Explain how random mutations such as those in pathogens with a mutator phenotype may arise in the <math alttext="D N A"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of an organism.

(b) Identify a dependent variable in the experiments. Identify the reasoning of the scientists when they tested the number of colonies produced by strains <math alttext="C 3 hyphen P B B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6 hyphen P B B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6-PBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The scientists also analyzed the number of colonies produced from each of the environmental and clinical isolate strains when the strains were plated on a growth medium lacking the toxic chemical. Justify this analysis.
(c) Based on the data in Figure 1, for each strain describe the relationship between the number of colonies observed and the likely mutation rate of the strain.

(d) State the null hypothesis for the experiment whose data are graphed in Figure 2. Provide evidence to support or refute the scientists’ claim that more colonies grew in strains <math alttext="C 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than in the other strains because the genes for proteins that are normally targeted by the toxic chemical contain nucleotides with incorrect bases in the <math alttext="C 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. The scientists additionally determined that the <math alttext="C 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C6</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strains had no decrease in virulence (disease-causing ability) in comparison with the virulence of the other clinical isolate strains and concluded that these two strains have mutator phenotypes. Explain why mutator phenotypes were found only among clinical isolate strains and not among environmental strains.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
